Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Rubber seed oil (RSO) with a high acid value was esterified under mild conditions with methanol to convert the free fatty acids in the RSO into methylesters in the esterified rubber seed oil (RSOE) and minimize the acid value as well. The peroxophosphatotungstate complexes were formed in the aqueous phase from the reaction between Na2WO4, H3PO4, and H2O2. Thanks to a cation exchange reaction with the phase-transfer catalyst (PTC), the catalytic complexes moved from phase to phase to perform their catalytic role. By studying a variety of factors influencing the epoxidation via the determination of oxirane oxygen, yield, conversion, and catalytic selectivity, the optimum conditions are found. They are as DB (double bond)/H2O2/Na2WO4 ratio of 1/2/0.0065, Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 ratio of 1/0.55/3 with RSOE, and 1/0.25/3 with RSO at 60°C for just one hour. The epoxidized rubber seed oil (ERSO) had an oxirane oxygen of 6.36% when 92.97% of the double bonds in the RSO were broken and 75.09% of the double bond was converted to the epoxide. These parameters would be 7.53%, 91.82%, and 88.91%, respectively for epoxidized esterified rubber seed oil (ERSOE). The catalyst selectivity for these reactions was significantly different, which was 0.81 for the high acid value RSO but 0.97 for the low acid value RSOE. Through the FTIR and NMR study, the success of the epoxidation has been shown. Keywords High acid value oil rubber seed oil peroxophosphatotungstate tungsten-based catalyst Epoxidation 1 Introduction The main component in vegetable oils, generally, is the triglycerides of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids. Through chemical reactions of double bonds, vegetable oils can be converted into other substances. The epoxidation is breaking down double bonds of the unsaturated fatty acid in vegetable oils to form epoxy groups. The epoxidizer can be either organic or inorganic, but the most common and environmentally friendly one is hydrogen peroxide. The catalysts used for the epoxidation are also very diverse. It can be acid catalyst, enzyme, ion exchange resin, Ti (IV)-grafted silica, transition metal complex, methyl trioxorhenium (VII) on nobia, tungsten- based catalyst, alumina, and Ti.SiO2 amorphous [1]. A tungsten-based catalyst was used by Payne (1959) to oxidize α,β-unsaturated acids with hydrogen peroxide in water [2], then by Venturello 1983 [3], and 1988 [4] for the olefin epoxidation reaction. Tungsten-based catalysis continues to be used by scientists to oxidize other double bonded compounds into epoxides as terminal olefins [5], unsaturated alcohols [6], olefins [7,8], alkenes [9], cyclopentene [10]. It is also used to oxidize oleic acid [11], fatty ester as methyl ester of sunflower [12], methyl oleate, methyl linoleate trioleic sunflower [13,14], and dimeric acid methyl ester derived from rubber seed oil [15], and ricinoleic acid methyl ester [16] into epoxy form. Furthermore, the tungsten-based catalyst is also used to oxidize vegetable oils into epoxides like sunflower oil [12,17], cotton oil and palm oil [17], rapeseed oil [13,14,17], and soybean oil [17-19]. The common point of the above works is that different tungsten-based complexes will be synthesized first and then used them as catalysts for the epoxidation reactions. Although a tungsten-based catalyst has long been used for the epoxidisation of vegetable oils and fatty esters, with the exception of the work of Xiaoan Nie and Jianchun Jiang [15], no papers refering to the use of this catalyst for the epoxidisation of rubber seed oil and its derivatives so far. In the work [15], those authors synthesized [π-C5H5NC16H33]3[PW4O16] in powder form and used it to epoxidize the dimeric acid methyl ester derived from rubber seed oil according to Zuwei Xi [7]. In the present work, the tungsten-based catalysts are also used for the epoxidation of rubber seed oil and its esterified derivatives. However, there is no need to synthesize the peroxo-phosphatotungstate catalytic complex in a powder form. It was generated in aqueous phase by the reaction of Na2WO4, H3PO4 and H2O2 and was added slowly to the oil phase. A phase-transfer catalyst (PTC) as benzyldimethylstearylammonium chloride hydrate, which has been added to the oil phase, helped the catalytic complex to move from phase to phase by a cation exchange reaction [20] to perform the catalytic role. Moreover, the esterified derivative with a low acid value was obtained by performing a high acid value rubber seed oil esterification reaction under the mild conditions to convert the free fatty acids in the oil into the methyl esters. In addition, the work has carried out a systematic study on the effect of the oxidant, the proportion of ingredients in the catalytic system, technological conditions on the epoxidation reaction of the rubber seed oil and esterified rubber seed oil as well as to evaluate the selectivity of the catalyst system. In particular, the influence of the acid value of the oils on the epoxidation using a tungsten-based catalyst was also considered. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Rubber seeds were collected in Long Khanh, Dong Nai, Vietnam. After 3 months of drying, they were pressed in EC company at 364/1 Cong Hoa, Tan Binh to get rubber seed oil (RSO) with iodine value of 146.9 cgI2/g and acid value of 39.03 mgKOH/g. Sodium tungstate dihydrate and Wijs solution were purchased from Merck, Germany. Phosphoric acid (85 wt.%), methanol, and hydrogen peroxide (30 wt.%) were obtained from Xilong Chemical, China. Hydrogen bromide solution (33 wt.%) was obtained from a Sigma-Aldrich, USA. Benzyldimethylstearylammonium chloride hydrate (PTC) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 Degumming of rubber seed oil The rubber seed oil (300 g) and distilled water (100 g) were heated to 50°C. The phosphoric acid (20 ml) was added gradually before the temperature reached 60°C. Stirring was maintained for 15 minutes before the mixture was stabilized in a separating funnel to remove the gum. 2.2.2 Esterification of rubber seed oil The gum free rubber seed oil and methanol with molar methanol/oil ratio of 7/1 were put into a reaction vessel. Then, the sulfuric acid was added drop by drop at 50°C while stirring. The reaction mixture was heated to 60°C and maintained at this temperature for a defined time. After finishing the reaction, the mixture was extracted, separated, washed with distilled water, and dried to obtain an esterified rubber seed oil product. 2.2.3 Epoxidation procedure The epoxidation reactions were carried out in a glass vessel of 2000 ml capacity at a motor rate of 250 rpm. A suitable amount of oil and PTC was taken in the vessel. Sodium tungstate dihydrate was dissolved in hydrogen peroxide with the presence of H3PO4. This mixture was added drop-wise into the vessel. Samples were withdrawn intermittently, considering the completion of H2O2 addition as zero time. The collected samples were extracted in a separating funnel, washed successively with cold, then slightly hot water to remove free acid, and then analyzed for iodine value and oxirane oxygen. 2.2.4 Analytical techniques The fatty acid compositions of oil were analysed according to ISO/FDIS 5590:1998 (Germany) standard by GC-MS with using an HP-6890 grafting Mass Selective Detector Agilent 5973. Column: HP – 5 ms (length 30 m - ID 0.25 mm – film thickness 0.25 μm), He: gas carrier, temperature program: 80 (1 min) – 40/min -150 (1 min) -10/min – 260 (10 min). Library mass spectrometry: WILEY275.L and NIST 98.L. `The conversion of double bonds to epoxy rings was observed under Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy on the Tensor 27 (Bruker) and nuclear magnetic resonance spectra on Bruker Avance 500, USA. The density, refractive index, and viscosity were determined by using a pycnometer 25 ml, Atago 1T (Japan), and Brookfield Model RVT, (Germany), respectively. The oil after degumming became clearer. However, rubber seed oil after gum separating still contains a high amount of free fatty acids. During the esterification with the methanol, the free fatty acids in the oil react with the methanol and are converted into methyl esters according to the reaction scheme (5), thus reducing the acidity of the oil. (5) (6) The acid value decreases gradually with esterification time (Table 1 ). The characteristics of the rubber seed oil and the esterified rubber seed oil after 8 reaction-hours are shown in Table 2 . The results of GC-MS analysis show that the fatty acid compositions of the 2 oils were similar with over 81% of unsaturated fatty acids. Their iodine values were the same while the acid value of RSOE was much smaller (Table 2). As can be seen from Fig. 1 , the H-NMR spectrum of RSOE has full proton resonance peaks a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and m similar to those of RSO. In addition, the signal i at 3.7 ppm corresponding to the proton of the methylene group adjacent to the OH group in diglycerides [21,22] appeared in the RSOE spectrum, but could not be seen in the spectrum of RSO. This proves that, in addition to triglycerides and methyl ester of free fatty acids being present in both oils, diglycerides exist in RSOE. However, monoglycerides are not found in either. Thus, besides the esterification reaction to convert the free fatty acids into the methyl ester (reaction 5) resulting in reducing the acid value of the oil, the transesterification is also taking place, the product of which is diglyceride (reaction 6). Our previous study [23] showed that only a small amount of the diglycerides was formed during the esterification of the rubber seed oils under such mild conditions. 3.2 The effect of oil's acid value on the epoxidation In this study, the epoxidation reactions were performed at 60°C with a mixing rate of 250rpm, the molar ratios of DB (double bond)/H2O2/Na2WO4, and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 were fixed at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/0.65/3, respectively. The effects of acid value of the oils on oxirane oxygen content, conversion, yield, and selectivity are shown in Fig. 2 . Regardless of the acid value of the oils, the oxirane oxygen increased rapidly in the first half hour of the reaction, that means the epoxidation reaction occurred quickly during this time. With all oils having different acid values, the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oils always reached maximum at one hour of the reaction, then decreased with the reaction time. The reduction in oxirane oxygen was attributed to the epoxy ring-opening reaction [13,17,24] (Fig. 2a). It is seen from the Fig. 2a, the oxirane oxygen curve of ERSO was at the lowest position, followed by the curve of ERSO0.25 and of ERSO1. This indicates that the oxirane oxygen of the epoxidized oils increased upon decreasing the acid value of the oils. As the acid value of the oils decreased further to 4.98 mgKOH/g, the oxirane oxygen content of the epoxidized oils increased. However, when it reduced to 1.12 mgKOH/g, the oxirane oxygen curve of ERSOE was still above the ERSO4 curve, but the distance between them was very close. The fact that the oxirane oxygen curves lie under the curves of ERSOE, and that the curves of low acid value oils lie close to each other is explained as follows. Epoxides are three-membered rings containing an oxygen atom. The high ring tension and strong electrophile reactivity make the epoxy ring more susceptible to reacting with a weak nucleophile in the acidic condition to open the ring. In this experiment, water is a weak nucleophile, so the ring opening reaction will take place under the SN-1 mechanism, which requires an acidic environment. That means the high acid value ​​oils actually promote the epoxy ring opening. Here, the acidity decreases from the RSO oil to the RSOE, so the ring-opening reaction will increase from ERSOE to ERSO, hence the oxirane oxygen of ERSOE was the highest and of ERSO was the lowest. The double bond acts as a nucleophile, it donates a pair of electrons to a proton. The acid value of the oil decreases from RSO to RSOE, the ability to donate a pair electrons of double bond decreases means that the ability to break double bonds will reduce, which leads to the conversion also decreases. As can be seen from Fig. 2b, when the acid value of the oil decreased from 39.03 to 4.98 mgKOH/g, the conversion after one hour of reaction dropped from 93.26 to 90.44%, but once it continued downward to 1.12 mgKOH/g the conversion changed negligibly (90.42%) (Fig. 2b). Thus, acid value is small enough, it would have little effect on the double bond breaking. The high acid-values ​​oils actually promote the double bond breaking, principally leading to high oxirane oxygen. Meanwhile, high acid-value oils also tend to open epoxy-ring more easily, which leads to the reduction in oxirane oxygen and obviously in yield. Thus, as the acid value of the oil decreases, the epoxy rings are more likely to be formed (Fig. 2a), consequently, it will get higher yield (Fig. 2b). After 1 hour of the reaction, the yield increased sharply, from 65.38 to 84.22% while the acid value of the oil reduced from 39.03 (RSO) to 7.85 mgKOH/g (RSO1). It raised slightly to 87.7% when the acid value of the oil fell to 1.12 mgKOH/g (RSOE). It is noticed in Fig. 2b, concerning RSO (high acid value), although 93.26% of the double bonds were broken, only 65.38% of them were transformed into epoxy rings, the reason of which could be the side reaction occurring and low catalytic selectivity (0.7). The decrease in the acid value of the oils reduced the double bond breaking but increased the epoxy ring formation, resulting in a sharp increase in the selectivity up to 0.97 (with RSOE). Fig. 2b shows that if the acid value of the oil is small enough, it has almost no effect on the epoxidation reaction, and the catalytic selectiviy shows to be high. 3.3 FTIR and HNMR Epoxidation reactions of the two oils were performed at 60°C, the mixing rate was 250rpm, the ratios of DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 were fixed at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/0.65/3, respectively. Two received epoxidized oils was analyzed for FTIR and HNMR, analytical spectra were shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 . The major absorption peaks of the functional groups on the RSO and RSOE FTIR spectra (Fig. 3) were a, b, c, d, e, and g. They correspond to the C-C bending of saturated C atoms, C-O stretching of esters, C-H bending of unsaturated alkane, C=O stretching of esters, C-H stretching of alkane, and C-H stretching of non-conjugated unsaturated, respectively. Comparing RSO with RSOE, it can be seen from Fig. 3, the peaks a, b, c, d, e and g appeared on both RSO and RSOE NMR spectra, but the peak n was only seen in the RSOE spectrum (Fig. 3b). Although this peak is not sharp and strong enough, it proved the presence of OH group on the RSOE’s molecular chains, which may be related to the transesterification reaction that forms, for example, diglycerides. This statement is supported by the above HNMR spectrum analysis with the presence of CH2 proton adjacent to the OH group. The absorption peak g at 3005.09 (Fig. 3a) and 3003.17 cm−1 (Fig. 3b) assigning to the C=C double bonds of the fatty acids are present in both RSOE and RSO spectra but not in ERSOE and ERSO one. This indicates that due to the epoxidation the double bonds have been altered. At the same time, the peaks m at 819.75 cm−1 (Fig. 3a) and 817.82 cm−1 (Fig. 3b) characterise the epoxy rings, newly appeared in ERSOE (Fig. 3a) and ERSO (Fig. 3b) spectra but are completely absent in the RSOE and RSO spectra. From the absorption peak -OH n at 3510.44 cm−1 in the ERSO spectrum (Fig. 3b), it can be assumed that beside the epoxy group formation, the epoxy ring-opening also occurs from which the OH group appears. The somewhat clearer OH-peak in the ERSO spectrum (Fig. 3b) as compared to that of the ERSOE spectrum (Fig. 3a) reaffirms that oils with a high acid value facilitated an epoxy ring-opening reaction, giving the rise to more OH groups. It is noticed from Fig. 4, the signal h at 0.8-1.0 ppm characterises the proton of the -CH3 group at the end of the chains, the signal g at 1.2-1.4 ppm is related to proton of the group - (CH2)n, the signal f at 1.6 ppm corresponds to the β-CH2-CH2-(C = O)O- group, and the signal d at 2.3 ppm stands for the proton of the α-CH2-(C = O) O- group. The proton signal b in CH2 of the methylene glycerol appears at 4.1-4.3 ppm, and that in -CH- of the glycerol methine, m, - at 5.2-5.3 ppm. All of them are present in both spectra of RSOE/ERSOE (Fig. 4a) and RSO/ERSO (Fig. 4b). In addition, in the RSOE and ERSOE spectra (Fig. 4a), the signal i of the proton in the -CH2 adjacent to the -OH in the diglycerides appears at 3.7 ppm. All the signals did not change in the modified process RSOE to ERSOE and RSO to ERSO. The peaks a at 5.3-5.4 ppm is related to proton of the -CH=CH- group, c at 2.7-2.8 ppm corresponds to the proton of the -CH2 between to two -CH=CH- groups, e at 2.0 ppm characterises for proton of β -CH2 to -CH=CH- group. They are present in the spectra of non epoxidised oil (RSOE and RSO) but not in the spectra of the epoxidised oil (ERSOE and ERSO). The new peaks n, k, and j appeared in the epoxidized oil spectrum correspond to the positions of peaks a, c, and e in the non-epoxidized oil spectrum (Fig. 4). For example, the peak k at 1.7 ppm is related to the CH2 proton between the two epoxy groups [21,22]. 3.4 Influence of the catalyst components on the RSO and RSOE epoxidation reaction 3.4.1 Sodium tungstate dihydrate In this experiment, a series of epoxidation reactions of the two oils was performed at 60°C, the mixing rate was 250rpm, the ratios of DB/H2O2 and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 were fixed at 1/2 and 1/0.65/3, respectively. The DB/Na2WO4 ratio changed from 1/0.0045 to 1/0.0075. The effect of tungstate content on the oxirane oxygen, conversion, and selectivity is shown in Fig. 5 . As can be seen from Fig. 5a, the oxirane oxygen of both ERSO and ERSOE increased and reached the maximum at one hour of reaction duration, then it decreased as the reaction went on. The decrease in the oxirane oxygen is believed to be due to the ring-openning reaction of the newly formed epoxy groups. The oxirane oxygen of ERSOE with all Na2WO4 content are significantly higher than those of ERSO. Regardless of the time and type of oils, the DB/Na2WO4 ratio changed from 1/0.0045 to 1/0.0065, and the oxirane oxygen raised significantly but it did not increase much when the DB/Na2WO4 ratio was further increasing. Fig. 5b presents the catalytic selectivity and the conversion of the RSO and RSOE epoxidation reaction at one hour in the relation to the tungstate content. The conversion of epoxidation reaction with both oils was high and raised slightly with the increase in Na2WO4 content. The high acid value of RSO promotes double bond breaking, so the conversion of RSO epoxidation reaction is always greater than that of RSOE. Due to the higher conversion and the lower yield, the catalytic selectivity in the RSO epoxidation reaction is less compared to that of the RSOE reaction. When the DB/Na2WO4 ratio increased from 1/0.0045 to 1/0.0065, the catalytic selectivity rose from 0.62 to 0.71 with RSO and from 0.92 to 0.97 with RSOE, but it was almost unchanged as the DB/Na2WO4 ratio kept increasing to 1/0.0075 (Fig. 5b). For all Na2WO4 content, the catalyst selectivity in the RSOE epoxidation reaction was much greater than that in the RSO reaction. The cause of this, again, may be due to the epoxy ring-opening reaction that occurred during the RSO epoxidation. 3.4.2 Phase-transfer catalyst Epoxidation is a reaction that occurs in the oil-water phase. The catalytic complex of tungsten salt with H2O2 oxidant is formed in the aqueous phase. This complex must move to the oil phase to catalyze the double bond breaking and the epoxy ring forming. Therefore, the effectiveness of the catalytic complex to catalyze the epoxidation will depend on its ability to move from the water to the oil phase. To increase the moving ability of the complex a co-catalyst called a PTC is additionally used. Alkyl-ammonium chloride (Q+Cl−) salt, as a PTC, will exchange its cation with the catalytic complex, and by this, help the complex in moving from the aqueous to the oil phase to catalyze the epoxidation. After that, the cation exchange occurs again to move the catalytic complex back to the aqueous phase. This cycle continues until the reaction completes [21]. In this study, a series of epoxidation reactions of two oils was performed at 60°C, the mixing rate was 250rpm. The ratios of DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/H3PO4 were fixed at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/3, respectively. The Na2WO4/PTC ratio changed from 1/0.15 to 1/0.65. The effect of PTC content on the oxirane oxygen, conversion, and selectivity is shown in Fig. 6 . As can be seen from Fig. 6a, at a small PTC content (1/0.15) the oxirane oxygen increased with an extension of the reaction time. Except for this ratio, the oxirane oxygen of both ERSOE and ERSO oils increased and reached maximum at one hour of reaction. The decrease in the oxirane oxygen with the reaction time prolongation is believed to be due to epoxy ring opening. The oxirane oxygen of ERSOE were always higher than that of ERSO, regardless of the PTC content and reaction time. When the Na2WO4/PTC ratio varied from 1/0.15 to 1/0.65, the oxirane oxygen of ERSO did not vary according to a rule. With the Na2WO4/PTC ratio of 1/0.25, it always reached the maximum oxirane oxygen for the ERSO. For RSOE, when the Na2WO4/PTC ratio changed from 1/0.45 to 1/0.65, the oxirane oxygen did not show much difference, but the highest oxirane oxygen was achieved when the Na2WO4/PTC ratio of 1/0.55 was used. It is seen from Fig. 6b, with a low Na2WO4/PTC ratio (1/0.15 for RSO), the conversion at one hour of reaction showed a low value. The conversion of both oils slightly raised upon further increase of the Na2WO4/PTC ratio. But their conversion figures are not much different. The catalytic selectivity of the RSOE epoxidation reached the maximum at the Na2WO4/PTC ratio of 1/0.55, meanwhile, for the RSO oil, the maximum was seen at the 1/0.25 ratio. At one hour of the reaction, the oxirane oxygen of ERSOE was much higher than that of RSO (Fig. 6a), while their reaction conversions were quite close to each other. So, it raises the assumption that the catalytic selectivity of the RSO epoxidation reaction would be much less than that of the RSOE (Fig. 6b). The cause of this is, in the epoxidation of RSO, the oil with high acid value, the epoxy ring-opening was easier to happen, reducing the reaction yield. Thus, the optimal Na2WO4/PTC ratio for the RSO is 1/0.25 while for the RSOE oil is 1/0.55. This difference can be explained as follows. PTC is a phase-transfer catalyst, it enhances the interaction between the oil and water phases in epoxidation reaction. Since RSO oil has a high acidity value, the hydrophilicity of RSO is higher than that of RSOE, so the demand for PTC will be less. 3.4.3 Ratio of Na2WO4/H3PO4 In the aqueous phase, the phosphotungstate catalyst formed on the basis of Na2WO4, H3PO4 and H2O2 according to the reaction scheme (7) and (8). (7) (8) The product can be a mixture of three complexes as PW-4, PW-3 or PW-2 with the activity listed in the order PW-4 > PW-3 > PW-2 [24]. Depending on the H3PO4 content, certain of these complexes will preferably be formed [3,4,25,26]. So, the content of H3PO4 will greatly affect the epoxidation. A series of epoxidation reactions of two oils was performed at 60°C with a mixing rate of 250rpm. The DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/PTC ratios were fixed, respectively, at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/0.25 (RSO) or 0.55 (RSOE). The ratio Na2WO4/H3PO4 changed from 1/2 to 1/3.5. Fig. 7 showed the relationship between the H3PO4 content and the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oils (Fig. 7a) as well as the conversion of reaction and the selectivity of the catalyst (Fig. 7b). As can be seen from Fig. 7a, the H3PO4 content affects greatly the oxirane oxygen of ERSO (dashed lines). At a small acid content (1/2 or 1/2.5) the catalytic complex may not be preferred to form PW-4, so the overall activity of the catalytic complex is lower, leading to a slower epoxy reaction. Only after 1.5 hours the oxirane oxygen of ERSO reached the maximum value. The oxirane oxygen increased and reached the maximum value at one hour of reaction when a higher Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio was used. In general, the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio increased from 1/2.0 to 1/3.0 the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oils increases sharply, but it reduced significantly if the ratio of 1/3.5 was used. When a catalyst complex in the aqueous phase is added to the oil phase, H3PO4 - a component of the catalytic complex - contributed to the acidity of the oil phase. Therefore, the higher the H3PO4 content, the higher the acidity in the oil phase, the stronger the epoxy-ring opening reaction will take place, leading to a sharp decrease in oxirane oxygen at the ratio of 1/3.5. The effect of the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio on the epoxidation of RSOE is similar to that of RSO. However, because the RSO oil itself is highly acidic, there will be a synergy effect of the two acidity on epoxidation. Therefore, when the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio changes, there is a clear difference in the oxirane oxygen for the ERSO, but not for the RSOE. In general, with both oils, the higher the H3PO4 content, the stronger the decrease in the oxirane oxygen of the epoxidized oil. The cause of this is more epoxy ring-opening occurs in the highly acidic medium. On the other hand, a small amount of H3PO4 will slow down the epoxidation reaction, as evidenced by the fact that oxirane oxygen reached the maximum at 1.5 hours of reaction instead of one hour. Therefore, a ratio of 1/3 is considered to be the most suitable for the reaction of both oils. At this ratio, the oxirane oxygen of the epoxidized oils was the highest. This may be because more active catalytic complexes are formed preferably at this ratio. The authors in [3,26] also showed that the catalytic activity or the type of the catalytic complexes formed depends on the pH of the aqueous phase. For both oils, the conversion was very high and only increased slightly upon increasing the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio (Fig. 7b). It is likely that the double bond fracture is less affected by the H3PO4 content. The oxirane oxygen of ERSO reached the largest value at the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio of 1/3 (Fig. 7a), meaning that the highest catalytic selectivity is also gained at the ratio of 1/3. The least possible side reactions would be when the epoxidation of RSO is conducted at the Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio of 1/3. Unlike RSO, the oxirane oxygen of ERSOE at one hour of the reaction reached a very high value, increased slightly upon a Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio raising from 1/2.0 to 1/3.0, but it decreased as the ratio continued to increase to 1/3.5 (Fig. 7a), resulting in a similar yield variation. Concerning the catalytic selectivity, for the RSOE epoxidation, it was very high (0.97), but was the lowest in a reaction using Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratio of 1/3.5 (Fig. 7b). Thus, the H3PO4 content influenced greatly the epoxidation of the high acid value RSO, but only slightly for the low acid value RSOE. In general, for all Na2WO4/H3PO4 ratios, the RSOE epoxidation gave a high oxirane oxygen ERSOE, the catalyst is of high selectivity, and negligible side reactions occur. 3.4.4 Hydroperoxide For this study, a variety of reactions have been performed with different DB/H2O2 ratios. The reaction temperature and mixing rate were fixed at 60°C and 250rpm, respectively. The ratios DB/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 were fixed, respectively, at 1/0.0065 and 1/0.25 (RSO) or 0.55 (RSOE)/3. The influence of the DB/H2O2 ratio on the oxirane oxygen, the conversion, and selectivity is presented in Fig. 8 . It notes that although the Na2WO4, H3PO4, and PTC contents are fixed, the H2O2 content changes, that is, the proportion of the complexes in the three complexes changes, so the overall activity of the catalytic system also changes and will affect the epoxidation reaction. The H2O2 content raise, the forming catalyst complexes also increase, epoxidation efficiency increases, so regardless of the oils the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oil grew up when the DB/H2O2 ratio changed from 1/1.5 to 1/2 (Fig. 8a). However, due to the fixed amount of Na2WO4 and H3PO4, the increase in H2O2 will decrease the acid activity in the aqueous phase, thereby reducing the overall activity of the catalytic complex, resulting in decrease in the epoxidation efficiency. Therefore, regardless of the oils, the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oils reduced strongly at the DB/H2O2 ratio of 1/2.5 and 1/3 (Fig. 8a). As can be seen from Fig. 8a, using low (1/1.5) or high (1/3) DB/H2O2 ratios, the oxirane oxygen of ERSO was small and increased to a maximum value at 1.5 hour. It got higher and reached a maximum at one hour for the remaining 6 reactions, meaning that these reactions occurred faster. The epoxy ring-opening reaction is obviously the cause of oxirane oxygen reduction. With the DB/H2O2 ratio of 1/2 and after one hour of the reaction, the oxirane oxygen reached the highest (7.53% for ERSOE and 6.36% for ERSO). It was much higher than the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oils when other DB/H2O2 ratios were used. Regardless of DB/H2O2 ratios and reaction time, the oxirane oxygen of ERSO was always much smaller than that of ERSOE. The variation of the reaction's yield follows the same rules as that of oxirane oxygen. Fig. 8b showed that the conversion of both RSO and RSOE was very high and reached a maximum at the DB/H2O2 ratio of 1/2. Thus, the catalyst selectivity in the RSO epoxidation reaction was much lower than that of the ERSOE one. For both RSO and RSOE, the catalyst selectivity at the DB/H2O2 ratio of 1/2 was always the highest. 3.5 Technological conditions 3.5.1 Temperature For this experiment, a variety of reactions have been performed at different temperatures. The mixing rate was fixed at 250rpm. The DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 ratios were fixed, respectively, at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/0.25 (RSO) or 0.55 (RSOE)/3. The effect of the temperature on the oxirane oxygen, conversion, and selectivity is presented in Fig. 9 . It is seen that when performing the reaction at 50°C, the oxirane oxygen of both ERSO and ERSOE increased with time. These parameters decrease immediately after 0.5 hours if the reactions were carried out at 80°C. This is obviously due to the ring-opening reaction that easier occurs at a high temperature. When the epoxidation was performed at 60 or 70°C, the oxirane oxygen reached a maximum at one hour. The decrease in the oxirane oxygen afterward is also explained by the occurring of epoxy ring-opening. However, it is noticed that there was more reduction of oxirane oxygen at 70°C as compared to that at 60°C (Fig. 9a). The oxygen oxirane of ERSOE is always much higher than that of ERSO, regardless of the temperature and the reaction time. This means that the oil with a low acid value is more favorable for the epoxidation reaction. The reaction temperature strongly affected the oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oil, which means it had a sharp impact on the yield of epoxidation reaction. Meanwhile, the conversion increased sharply when reaction temperature was elevated from 50 to 60°C, but it raised only slightly if the temperature was higher (Fig. 9b). While the oxirane oxygen of ERSOE is always much higher than that of ERSO, regardless of the temperature (Fig. 9a), the conversions of both RSO and RSOE epoxidation reaction were nearly the same, so the catalyst selectivity of RSO epoxidation reaction was much smaller than that of RSOE one (Fig. 9b). In general, for both oils, the catalyst selectivity is always highest when the reactions were conducted at 60°C and the value of selectivity depends much on the oil's acid value. 3.5.2 Mixing rate As with any chemical reaction, the effectiveness of epoxidation depends also on the reactant's intraction. The stir helps greatly in enhancing the reactant's interaction. For the study, a variety of epoxidation reactions were performed at different stirring rates while reaction temperature was fixed at 60°C. The DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 and Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 ratios were fixed respectively at 1/2/0.0065 and 1/0.25 (RSO) or 0.55 (RSOE)/3. The effect of stirring rate on the oxirane oxygen, conversion, and selectivity is shown in Fig. 10 . The RSO has a higher viscosity (Table 2), so when performing the reaction at a low mixing rate (230 rpm), the interaction between the oil phase and the water phase is not favorable, so the epoxidation efficiency is also not high, the epoxidation reaction took place quite slowly. It took 1.5 hours to reach the maximal oxirane oxygen. Stirring rate increased, the interaction increased, the epoxidation efficiency increased, so the oxirane oxygen raised. It took one hours to reach the maximal oxirane oxygen. However, when the mixing rate is large enough, the interaction between the two phases will not depend much on the stirring rate, resulting in a slight increase in oxirane oxygen. Unlike RSO, RSOE has a smaller viscosity, so the interaction between two oils and water phases will be less affected by the mixing rate. Therefore, the oxirane oxygen of ERSOE was not much different when the mixing rate changed (Fig. 10). While the stirring rate affected the yield, it barely had any effect on the conversion of both oils. This can clearly be seen from the conversion curves for both oils in Fig. 10b which were very high and almost horizontal. Therefore, the catalyst selectivity's values of RSOE epoxidation reactions at different mixing rates were very high and almost equal, however, they differed greatly for RSO epoxidation reaction. The catalyst selectivity of RSO epoxidation reaction reached the highest of 0.81 when the reaction was done at the stirring rate of 250 rpm. Thus, both yield and selectivity are influenced by the stirring rate if the used oil has a high acid value. 4 Conclusion Until now, when studying the epoxidation of olefins, alkene, fatty acids or vegetable oils, the acidity of the starting materials was not mentioned due to their low values. For the first time, the epoxidation of vegetable oils with a very high acid value, namely rubber seed oil (RSO), was studied. The behavior of the rubber seed oil in epoxidation has been compared to that of an oil with a low acidity value, namely esterified rubber seed oil (RSOE). A tungsten salt-based catalyst system has been used for the epoxidation of these two oils and the results are quite impressive. High acid value (RSO) oil will give higher conversion of reaction while the yield, oxirane oxygen of epoxidized oil and catalytic selectivity were lower. The effectiveness of the catalyst depends on the acidity of both the aqueous and oil phases. For oils with low acid value, the efficiency of epoxidation does not depend much on the content of H3PO4 - a component of the catalytic system. Meanwhile, for high acid value oil, this dependence is very clear. High acid value oils are more hydrophilic, hence, there is lower need for PTC usage in the reaction. The experiment also shows that the optimum ratio of Na2WO4/PTC is 1/0.25 for RSO oil and 1/0.55 for RSOE. The process of esterification converting RSO to RSOE reduces the viscosity of the oils, so the epoxidation of RSOE will be less affected by the stirring rate. A variety of influencing factors were studied to give the optimum conditions for epoxidation of each oil. These included the DB/H2O2/Na2WO4 ratio of 1/2/0.0065, Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 ratio of 1/0.55/3 for RSOE and 1/0.25/3 for RSO. The reaction took place for only one hour at temperature of 60°C and striring rate of 250 rpm. The epoxidized oils also have very different characteristics (Table 2). The oxirane oxygen of ERSOE is 7.53% while ERSO is only 6.36%. coredata.dc:description: Rubber seed oil (RSO) with a high acid value was esterified under mild conditions with methanol to convert the free fatty acids in the RSO into methylesters in the esterified rubber seed oil (RSOE) and minimize the acid value as well. The peroxophosphatotungstate complexes were formed in the aqueous phase from the reaction between Na2WO4, H3PO4, and H2O2. Thanks to a cation exchange reaction with the phase-transfer catalyst (PTC), the catalytic complexes moved from phase to phase to perform their catalytic role. By studying a variety of factors influencing the epoxidation via the determination of oxirane oxygen, yield, conversion, and catalytic selectivity, the optimum conditions are found. They are as DB (double bond)/H2O2/Na2WO4 ratio of 1/2/0.0065, Na2WO4/PTC/H3PO4 ratio of 1/0.55/3 with RSOE, and 1/0.25/3 with RSO at 60°C for just one hour. The epoxidized rubber seed oil (ERSO) had an oxirane oxygen of 6.36% when 92.97% of the double bonds in the RSO were broken and 75.09% of the double bond was converted to the epoxide. These parameters would be 7.53%, 91.82%, and 88.91%, respectively for epoxidized esterified rubber seed oil (ERSOE). The catalyst selectivity for these reactions was significantly different, which was 0.81 for the high acid value RSO but 0.97 for the low acid value RSOE. Through the FTIR and NMR study, the success of the epoxidation has been shown.
coredata.dc:title: Epoxidation of vietnam rubber seed oil by using peroxophosphatotungstate catalyst complex based on Na2WO4/H3PO4/H2O2 with the presence of phase-transfer catalyst
